title: The role of retrieval processes in false recognition
abstractText:
The aim of the proposed research is to identify the role of retrieval processes and the importance of backward associative strength (BAS) in the creation of false memories produced using associative (DRM like lists) and categorised lists.

We will investigate whether associations at test contribute to memory illusions or whether errors occur simply due to impairments in source monitoring.

The proposed research will also investigate differences in backward associative strength for both DRM and categorised word lists and will look at the role this has on false memory production. There will be two main phases to this investigation.

The first phase will investigate the role of source-monitoring errors and semantic activation on false memory production when using the test-induced priming procedure. For the second phase of this investigation DRM and categorised lists will be designed and matched for BAS. False recognition and recall is generally higher for DRM lists compared to categorised lists, and differences in BAS of these lists may explain why. Differences in BAS will be investigated by manipulating BAS scores within both DRM and categorised lists.
